drupalNodeEvent.title: ‘Scientific’ Management in Republican Shanghai: American-Returned Students and the Concept of Efficiency

field_organizers.processed: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: This paper examines the introduction of ‘scientific’ management in Republican Shanghai through its first translators, the academic Yang Xingfo and the industrialist Mu Xiangyue. Both were American-returned students who embraced the ideas of Frederick Winslow Taylor as potential solutions to China’s ills. Like many Republican elites, they subscribed to dismissal assessments of their fellow countrymen and worked to integrate Taylorism across Chinese society as a technocratic tool to control and reform the unwashed masses. From the textile industry and cotton agriculture to vocational education and personal behavior, they worked with networks of fellow reformers and American-returned students to transform the Chinese people into more efficient and thereby more productive and valuable citizens in their eyes.
